Your NinjaPCR is unplugged from the computer.
Plug in your NinjaPCR to get updated information on your run.

console.updateRequired: Device update is required. It can't run without updating.
console.updateStarting: Starting device update. Please do not turn the power off.
console.updating: Device is updating. Please do not turn the power off.
console.updateFailed: Device update was failed. Please try again.
console.wifiSettingsButton: Setup a new NinjaPCR device / Change network configuration
console.wifiSettings0: Plug the power adapter into NinjaPCR and then into an outlet.
console.wifiSettings1: Press the "Mode" button and hold it, then press and release the "Reset" button while the "Mode" button is pressed. NinjaPCR will start in access point (AP) mode in a few seconds.
console.wifiSettings2: Open the settings of your PC or smartphone and select "NinjaPC" shown in the AP list.
console.wifiSettings3: Open the WiFi settings page and setup. If the page doesn't show up, please retry after a few seconds.
console.wifiSettings3_0: Choose the SSID (network name) you want to use from the dropdown menu. If you can't find it in the list, input the SSID to the textbox below.
console.wifiSettings3_1: Input the password of the network.
console.wifiSettings3_2: Device name: You can name your NinjaPCR with alphanumeric letters. The number of letters should be between 4 to 8. The default name "ninjapcr" is good enough if you use only one device, but it's recommended to use different names if you (and nearby users)  have multiple NinjaPCR devices.
console.wifiSettings3_3: After you set up the device, it will restart and connect to the specified access point.
console.wifiSettings4: Connect your PC of smartphone to the WiFi access point that your NinjaPCR is connected to.
console.wifiSettings5: Input the "Device name" that you have specified when you configured the device and press "connect" button.
console.androidGuide: You need to install NinjaPCR app. Please install the app on Play Store.

wifi.title: WiFi
wifi.text1: Accessible from local network / Access point mode without a Wi-Fi router

accuracy.title: Accuracy
accuracy.text3: Temperature simulation of sample in tubes

open.title: Open-source
open.text1: All source codes and scematics are available on GitHub

items.title: Keep Serial Number
items.text1: Serial Number is important to get support in the warranty period. It's labeled on warranty and circuit board as S/N:xxx-xxx-xxx but digital backup is recommended.

items.title: High Temperature
items.text1: Some parts get heated up to 120 degree celcius (250 degree fahrenheit). Do not touch aluminium parts directly. Top of PCR tube is still host just after PCR process has ended.

items.title: High Current
items.text1: Peltier in kit supports up to 10 Ampere. Do not touch circuit board while using. Keep it away from water and any conductive materials.

items.title: Android needs App
items.text1: Supported OS versions are 4.1 (Jelly Baen) and later. For Android User : Please install
items.text2: app
items.text3: to use.

items.title: Opensource
items.text1: This is totally opensourced hardware under GNU General Public License v3.0. You can get everything (3D model, circuit diagram, sourcecode, laser cut data and so on) from
items.text2: GitHub

items.title: You have tools
items.text1: 2 phillips screwdrivers, straight driver, multi spanner and grease spatula are bundled inside plastic bag.

items.title: Hint
items.text1: Laser cut wood has face and tail. It will look good if you always choose face side (logo on front panel) to be shown even it's symmetric.

unbox.label: Unboxing
unbox.text1: Before assembly, take a breath and confirm that you have everything needed. If you find anything missed or broken,
unbox.text3: with seriall number in warranty period.

head: Kit Content
Detail
Count
body: Check printed circuit board is not damaged
Heatsink and spare thermal conductive grease are packed in one box

head: Bag Content
Detail
Count
body: Aluminium PCR tube holder. Thin wires of thermistor are especially FRAGILE. Handle with care.
Use these ones first. If you need more, use spare grease in heatsink box.

items.title: All Parts
items.text1: Screw Bag 1, Knob and these woods are needed.

head: Name
Detail
Count
body: Support heater to go up and down.
2 small holes for hinge and 1 bigger hole for calbes of heater

head: Name
Detail
Count
body: With 4 wires. Pink ones are thermistor inside.
Cover one side of heater to avoid convection
Plate with 4 holes on each corners

items.title: Floating Heater
items.text1: Peel off blue tape from aluminium plate. Screw 4 longer screws (M3 15mm) and nuts like this.
items.text2: Peel double-sided tape from heater. Glue heater to the midst of aluminium plate. Don't colide with screws nor nuts.
items.text3: Peel off double-sided tape on sponge and cover the heater.
items.text4: Screw heater lift wood with 4 nuts. Now heater unit is done.

items.title: Lid Base
items.text1: Assemble box with remained 4 screws and 4 spacers.
items.text2: Place heater unit inside and thread all 4 wires of heater through the hole of lid back wood. Wires must be behind the spacer (blue arrow) not front (red arrow). Check that heater unit can move up and down somoothly without catching cables.

items.title: Lid Cover
items.text1: Screw lid top wood with last 4 screws and put a knob. Now you have made lid.

items.title: All Parts
items.text1: Screw Bag 2, Well, Heatsink + Spare Grease and these woods are needed.

head: Name
Detail
Count
body: Wider area is front side (bottom in picture). Asymmetric : hole for cable (red circle) will come to the top-right when face side is up.

head: Name
Detail
Count
body: High temperature durable silicon sealed peltier
To avoid airflow from body to lid

items.title: Woods
items.text1: Connect heatsink holder and top board with 4 thick screws (M5 20mm) and nuts firmly using offset driver and multi spanner. Both front sides (arrow) must be aligned.

items.title: Well
items.text1: Screw remained 4 thin screws (M3 6mm) and nuts loosely first. Place side of nut (red rectangle) can be seen from each side. You can place well into holder easier at next step.
items.text2: Turn well upside down. Tune directions of nus to fit the notches of heatsink holder and screw tightly. Confirm thermistor of well (red circle) is sticking out to front (arrow).

items.title: Peltier
items.text1: Paste grease over backside of well. No need to squeeze it all. Use spatula to smooth evenly.
items.text2: Align 2 wires of peltier over notchs of heatsink holder (arrows) and put peltier on well like this. DO NOT mistake red and black! That will break peltier easily.
items.text3: Thread thermistor sensors through peltier holder and connect it to heatsink holder with 2 thin-long screws (M3 15mm) and nuts. It's a bit difficult because heads of screws are downside. Confirm that thermistor wires of well are OVER peltier holder (red circle) and peltier wires are running through holes made by holders (arrows).

items.title: Aluminium Plate
items.text1: Smooth grease over peltier evenly as you have done over well.
items.text2: Peel off blue tape from aluminium plate. Put it over peltier and press a little.

items.title: Heatsink
items.text1: Hold white leg of heatsink in left hand. Rotate counterclockwise black cap and pull by right hand. Then it will be removed easily. Remove all 4 legs.
items.text2: Peel off cover sticker of heatsink and smooth grease. If there is no grease left, use spare.
items.text3: Screw heatsink with holders with remained 4 nuts (M5). Use multi spanner to screw tightly. At this point, you may see small gap between heatsink and aluminium plate (arrow).
items.text4: Turn upside down and push well downward so that there is no gap between heatsink and aluminium plate (arrow).

items.title: Fill Space
items.text1: Fill the gap between well and top board with sponge using straight driver. No need to put it deeply because purpose of this sponge is not to warm well but avoid airflow from bottom body to lid. Just fill the gap.

items.title: Mount Lid
items.text1: Mount lid and thread 4 wires throught hole (arrow). Screw hinge on backside of the lid with 4 tapping screws. There are pilot holes. Use phillips screwdriver first then screw it firmly with offset driver.
items.text2: Screw bottom latch in front of lid with 2 tapping screws tightly. There are pilot holes too.
items.text3: Top latch is adjustable and lid should be closed firmly. Screw it with 2 tapping screws loosely first.
items.text4: Screw tightly while holding lid to top board.
items.text5: It's not safe if 4 wires of heater not fastened because fan of heatsink will catch them easily. Peel off release paper from wire clip. Put it in front side of top board and fasten 4 wires by bending thin part of clip. Check that you can open/close lid smoothly and firmly. Now you have made upper body.

items.title: All Parts
items.text1: Screw Bag 3, PCB, Fanguard, Rubber foot and these woods are needed.

head: Name
Detail
Count
body: PCB will be placed behind logo.

items.title: Bottom Wood
items.text1: Screw fanguard on TAIL of bottom board with 4 thick screws (M4 10mm) and nuts. Then face will be upside and it looks better.
items.text2: Connect 60mm and 30mm spacers to make 4 90mm spacers.
items.text3: Screw 4 rubber foot to bottom board with 4 thin long screws (M3 15mm) and spacers.
items.text4: Put all side boards except front.
items.text5: Mount upper body and pull cables out to front. Don't screw upper body yet.

items.title: Circuit Board
items.text1: Screw PCB on backside of front board with 4 thin long screws (M3 15mm), 4 spacers (M3 5mm) and nuts. Power connector should come to the right side of logo.

items.title: Wiring
items.text1: Connect longest heatsink cable. It wont be locked if it's in wrong direction.
items.text2: Loose 6 screws of all 3 green terminal blocks by screwing counterclockwise using straight driver.
items.text3: Connect 2 power cables of heater (white). No matter which white cable to be right or left but DO NOT connect pink cables. It will break thermistor.
items.text4: Connect 2 thermistor calbes of heater (pink). No matter which is right or left.
items.text5: Connect RED cable of peltier to the hole with arrow. DO NOT connect to next hole wrongly. That will break peltier.
items.text6: Connect BLACK cable to the remained hole. DO NOT connect to next hole wrongly.
items.text7: Wires of well thermistor are short and fragile. We connect it to PCB on next paragraph.

items.title: Well thermistor
items.text1: Last but most sensitive part of whole assembly process. Lift top/right/left boards a little and set front board.
items.text2: Lift up top board a little and connect well thermistor to the pinheads (circle).
items.text3: Bak top board softly and screw it with remained 4 screws (M3 15mm).

items.title: Connect power adapter
items.text1: Plug the power adapter into NinjaPCR and then into an outlet.
items.text2_1: If you are planning to use NinjaPCR with only "access point (AP) mode" without connecting a local Wi-Fi network, please skip this page and jump to "

items.title: Start in access point (AP) mode
items.text1: Press the "Mode" button and hold it, then press and release the "Reset" button while the "Mode" button is pressed. NinjaPCR will start in access point (AP) mode in a few seconds.

items.title: Change your Wi-Fi settings temporarily
items.text1: Open the settings of your PC or smartphone and select "NinjaPCR" shown in the AP list. Its conenction password is "ninjapcr".
items.text2: macOS
items.text3: Click the Wi-Fi icon in the menu bar and select "NinjaPCR" from the list.
items.text4: Windows
items.text5: Click the Wi-Fi icon in the menu bar and select "NinjaPCR" from the list.
items.text7: From your Home screen open "Settings" and go to "Wi-Fi" screen. Choose "NinjaPCR" from the list.
items.text9: Open "Settings" and move to "Wireless & networks" screen. Select "NinjaPCR" in the AP list.

items.title: Access the Wi-Fi settings page
items.text1: Open
items.text2: Wi-Fi settings page (http://192.168.1.1)
items.text3: and setup. If the page doesn't show up, please retry after a few seconds.

items.title: Input Wi-Fi Settings
items.text1: SSID
items.text2: Choose the SSID (network name) you want to use from the dropdown menu. If you can't find it in the list, input the SSID to the textbox below.
items.text3: Password
items.text4: Input the password of the network.
items.text6: Device name: You can name your NinjaPCR with alphanumeric letters. The number of letters should be between 4 to 8. The default name "ninjapcr" is good enough if you use only one device, but it's recommended to use different names if you (and nearby users)  have multiple NinjaPCR devices.
items.text7: After you set up the device, it will restart and connect to the specified access point.

items.title: Restore Wi-Fi settings
items.text1: Connect your PC of smartphone to the Wi-Fi access point that your NinjaPCR is connected to as you have done in

items.title: Open the console
items.text1: After finishing Wi-Fi setup, NinjaPCR will restart in normal operation mode and become accessible from the console. Please test the connection.
items.text2: Windows / macOS / Linux / iOS
items.text3: Open
items.text4: the console
items.text9: from Google Play Store and open it.

items.title: Input the device name
items.text1: Input the "Device name" that you have specified when you configured the device and press "Connect" button.

items.title: Connection test
items.text1: Connection has succeeded if you see the "Connected" message. Then NinjaPCR is ready! If you see the "Disconnected" message again, it means that something went wrong. NinjaPCR needs some seconds to become accessible so trying again a little later may resolve the problem. If the problem still persists, please refer to
items.text2: Troubleshooting > Connection test fails

items.title: Troubleshooting
items.text1: "NinjaPCR" does not appear on the AP list
items.text1_1: Your device can't catch the signal if it's far away from NinjaPCR. Please try again near NinjaPCR.
items.text1_2: Some devices take time to find  new access points. If many APs are listed up, NinjaPCR is listed out of the screen. Please scroll it.
items.text1_3: It is possible that "Mode" and "Reset" buttons had not been released properly. Please reboot NinjaPCR again by pressing and releasing buttons slowly.
items.text2: Dropdown list on NinjaPCR's Wi-Fi settings page doesn't contain the SSID you want to use.
items.text2_1: Access poitns of some types don't show up in the list. For example, an access point in stealth mode is hidden. Some smartphones in tethering mode don't listed up. In such cases, please input the SSID's name to the textbox below and choose nothing from the dropdown list.
items.text3: Connection test fails
items.text3_1: Start NinjaPCR in access point (AP) mode again and you'll find a message at the bottom of the Wi-Fi settings page. It indicates what happened when NinjaPCR started last time. If it reads "Connection error", it means that NinjaPCR failed to join the network due to wrong settings. If it "Connected", it means that NinjaPCR succeessfully join the network and the problem was caused by client side(your PC, smartphone or tablet).
items.text3_2: Your device and NinjaPCR should connect to the same network. Please review Wi-Fi settings of both.
items.text3_3: Did you correctly started NinjaPCR in normal operation, not in access point (AP) mode? You don't need to press "Mode" button.
items.text3_4: NinjaPCR uses a mechanism called "mDNS" to be accessible from other devices. mDNS is available by default in macOS and iOS. Though Windows and Linux have mDNS helper application in most cases, if your PC doesn't have it, please install a helper software.
items.text14: . It is one of the easiest way to install mDNS support.
items.text18: . Avahi is a very popular software and most distributions support it with their own package systems.

items.title: Initial setup
items.text1: Network configuration is needed when you use NinjaPCR for the first time. If you have not done yet, please refer to
items.text2: document.

items.title: Manage experiment profiles
items.text1: You can create an experiment profile to run it just once or save it to use repeatedly.
items.text2: Create
items.text3: To create a new experiment profile, click "+" icon. Profile editor will open.
items.text4: Edit
items.text5: A profile consists of one or more cycles. A cycle has some steps and repeat counts.
items.text6: Each step has duration and temperature. If you need to cool or heat samples very slowly, you can set ramp time (shortest transition time) to a step. If ramp time is empty, NinjaPCR tries to change temperature as fast as possible.
items.text7: If your need a complex profile with cycles with multiple patterns, click "More Options" button to add cycles. Temperature of the lid is 110 Celsius by default but you can customize it by changing "Heater Lid" value.
items.text8: For example, the profile below is written as screenshot images below.
items.text28: To save your edit, click "Save Preset" button.
items.text29: Profiles are saved in storage area of your web browser. They are deleted by erasing data by browser settings. You can't save of load profiles in modes which don't allow usage of storage functionalities.
items.text31: A profile can be deleted by the trash bin icon.

items.title: Set tubes
items.text1: Open the lid.
items.text2: Insert tubes to the well.
items.text3: Close the lid.
items.text4: Turn the knob clockwise to press tubes lightly with the lid.

items.title: Start an Expriment

ap.title: Access point (AP) mode
ap.text1_0: Power the NinjaPCR while holding the "MODE" button on the front panel. Then it starts in access point (AP) mode.
ap.text1_1: Learn more about access point (AP) mode
ap.text2_0: While using access point (AP) mode, your device cannot access sites other than NinjaPCR. It is recommended that you download the offline console beforehand.
ap.text3_2: and expand it into your local disk.
ap.text7: Open the console, select "Access point (AP) mode" and press "connect" button.

items.text1: Plug the power adapter into NinjaPCR and then into an outlet. Then open the console screen and input the "Device name" that you have specified when you configured the device and press "Connect" button.
items.text2: Open the profile screen. You can create a new profile by clicking "+" icon or load an existing profile by choosing from the dropdown and click the "Re-run" button.
items.text3: When PCR is running, temperature of the well and the lid and estimated temperature.
items.text4: You can abort the experiment, click "Stop" button.

items.title: After an Experiment
items.text1: When the profile is all done, "Finished" is displayed.
items.text2: Open the lid and take out tubes. Please be careful not to touch the well or the lid. They are very hot after for several minutes!
items.text3: Plug the power adapter out.

items.title: Making NinjaPCR from scratch
items.text1: NinjaPCR is totally opensourced on
items.text2: GitHub
items.text3: . Bill of materials(BOM) is
items.text4: here
items.text5: . Making NinjaPCR from scratch is best way to experience multiple DIY skills like lasercutting, metal, electric circuits and so on at once. But it's really hard for beginners to accomplish by themselves without any help. That is why this section exists! We designed "Maker model" (left) besides "Kit model" (right, on sale). By sharing detailed instructions how to make Maker model from scratch, we hope that people get DIY skills much easier and apply their knowledges to another creative projects in future.

items.title: Differences between Kit model and Maker model
items.text1: Latch and Hinge
items.text2: Kit model uses parts only on market in Japan. In Maker model, they are replaced with laser cut wood and no need to import.
items.text3: ATX Power Supply
items.text4: Adapter of Kit model is powerful due to run peltier (12V150W). You can find it on
items.text6: but it will cost a lot including shipping fee. In Maker model, you can add ATX connector to PCB and choose another
items.text8: with hole for connector so that you can plug ATX power supply that can be scavenged easily from broken PC. In that case, no need to solder 2 adapter connetors (DIN4 and JACK) on PCB.
items.text10: You can solder additional pinheads just above ATX connector to write program using
items.text14: . By sticking jumpoer pin to IO0, firmware can be replaced.
items.text16: Kit model uses 5.5mm MDF (Medium-density fibreboard). Choose from 5.0mm and 5.5mm in Maker model.

items.title: Advantages
items.text1: Cheap (maybe or not)
items.text2: If you want to save money by making from scratch, we don't recommend. For example,
items.text3: well (tube holder)
items.text4: is USD100 on our shop but you will spend at least 20 hours or USD300 for outsourcing.
items.text6: is USD80 and we will share how to search on online market and a link trying to make it at USD0.5. But that might be easy to be broken by heat and we have never tried before. Keep in mind that you have to take all responsibilities even if you make a fire by sparks due to such fault. It is almost impossible to make safe heater with high thermal density in small amount because mold is needed. As a conclusion, we cannot assure that Maker model is cheaper than Kit model
items.text8: Relax, you don't need to make everything. Even if you make only wood parts by touching laser cutter in
items.text12: around you for the first time, you will notice that you got super power and great connections throughout your life. You can complement on our shop and we will help you if you ask questions through

items.title: Disadvantages
items.text1: No Warranty
items.text2: Kit model has some warranty but nothing with Maker model. You have to understand that you are responsible for everything that happens.
items.text3: Endurance
items.text4: You might feel everything doesn't work as you want first. When we cannot point out the root cause online, you may have to repeat or test with patience. Don't scared to make faults.

items.title: Components
items.text1: NinjaPCR are consisted from these components. Some components need proper tools like laser cutter. Even if you don't have, you can buy them on
items.text2: shop

items.title: Wood Parts
items.text1: Cut MDF (Medium-density fibreboard) with thickness 5.0mm or 5.5mm using laser cutter.

items.title: Printed Circuit Board (PCB)
items.text1: First, we will order green "Printed Circuit Board (PCB)" and "Stencil" to factory by uploading proper files online. Then we will order electric parts on another online stores. Surface Mount Devices (SMD) will be "reflowed" (soldered using stencil and solder paste). Other parts will be soldered by soldering rod. "Reflow" is a common technique to solder small parts at once and people share how to do that using cheap tools like hot plate or oven.

items.title: Well
items.text1: Aluminium PCR tube holder. Like PCB, there is web service that you can order metal parts by uploading 3D model but that would be pricy (maybe more than USD300/piece for small amount). To make by youself, buy A6063 aluminium plate first. Then operate 3D CAD software to export CAM (Computer-aided manufacturing) file for CNC. Finally, run CAM file on CNC machine to mill part you need.

items.title: Lid Heater
items.text1: Lid heater works as dew condensation prevention. Without heating top of tube at high temperature (around 110 degree celcius), solution vapors and liquefy into drops atop of tube.
items.text2: Cheap heaters
items.text3: don't have enough thermal density and it cannot or takes too long time to reach high temperature. We introduce how to make it using PCB but it is not recommended.

items.title: Aluminium Plates
items.text1: 40x52mm and 40x40mm aluminium plates. Thickness can be varied from 1.5 to 2.0mm. Any kind of aluminium works well. You can cut such thin aluminium with box cutter easily.

items.title: PC Parts
items.text1: Common LGA115x heatsink, grease and ATX power supply can be used. Maximum operating temperature of common peltier is around 80 degree celcius though PCR process requires up to 100 degree celcius. We recommend Hebei TEC1-12710HTS Peltier Module with maximum operating temperature of 225 degree celcius.

items.title: Screws
items.text1: Just get the screws, nuts and spacers in list.

items.title: Miscellaneous
items.text1: All items in list are common or easy to find.

items.title: Working area of laser cutter
items.text1: Visit nearest DIY place with laser cutter like
items.text2: hackerspaces
items.text3: and
items.text4: FabLab
items.text5: and check required data format and working area (maximum size of wood you can place inside). If it is wider than 367x450mm, you can cut all parts at once. Otherwise, repeat several times with smaller boards.

items.title: Thickness of wood plate
items.text1: Check Medium Density Fibreboard (MDF) at your nearest DIY stores. Choose 5.0mm or 5.5mm for thickness and buy required amount of boards. They might cut your board into proper size.

items.title: Prepare Data
items.text1: You can find data for
items.text2: Inkspace
items.text4: PDF
items.text9: . No data for Adobe illustrator but you can import PDF.

items.title: Time to Cut
items.text1: Bring MDF and data to your laser cutter. Congratulations, you made wood parts by yourself.

items.title: Order PCB and Stencil
items.text1: NinjaPCB is the name of PCB for NinjaPCR. Let's order its latest version 2.2 online at
items.text2: Seeed Fusion PCB
items.text3: . All required files are located
items.text4: here
items.text7: and never forget to change "Copper Weight" from default 1oz to 2oz. You can order stencil at the same time that is required to solder small parts with hand.

items.title: Order Electric Parts
items.text1: Here is the list to solder. If you use ATX power supply instead of adapter, no need to solder JACK nor DIN4 but ATX. You can choose WiFi module from cheaper
items.text2: ESP-12F
items.text3: (FCC, CE) or
items.text4: ESP-WROOM-02
items.text5: (FCC, CE, SRRC, TELEC, IC, KCC). Check which license is needed in your country. It is hard to find Heatsink and Relay outside Tokyo so we will sell it on shop. NinjaPCB is designed and tested with
items.text7: . Keep in mind that some alternatives in this list are not yet tested.

items.title: Preparing
items.text1: Please Stand By.

items.title: Burn Firmware
items.text1: This page describes how to build NinjaPCR's firmware and write it to the ESP8266 chip on the board. A USB-serial cable and a jumper pin is required.

items.title: Install Arduino IDE
items.text1: Access
items.text2: , then download and install the latest Arduino IDE to your PC.

items.title: Install the ESP8266 add-ons
items.text1: Arduino IDEはそのままではESP8266用のプログラムをビルドしたり書き込みを行ったりすることができません。
items.text2: サードパーティ製のハードウェアをサポートするライブラリやボード設定やツールをインストールする "Board Manager" という仕組みを利用し、ESP8266に対応する必要があります。
items.text3: まず、"Preferences" で "Additional Board Manager URLs" に
items.text4: を追加します。
items.text5: Arduinoのツールバーから "Tools > Board: > Boards Manager..." を選択し、"esp8266 by ESP8266 Community" をインストールします。
items.text6: バージョンは2.4.2以上を選択してください。
items.text7: Arduino IDE経由ではなくGitHubのリポジトリからcloneして手動でインストールするという方法もあります。詳しくは
items.text8: ESP8266ライブラリのGitHubリポジトリ

items.title: Download the source code of NinjaPCR
items.text2: GitHub上のNinjaPCRリポジトリ
items.text3: からソースコードをダウンロードします。zipでダウンロードして解凍するか、gitを利用して
items.text4: をcloneしてください。
items.text7: ビルド設定を選びます。"Board" は "Generic ESP8266 Module" を選択します。
items.text8: ESP8266にはEEPROM容量が2MBと4MBのものが流通していますので、2MBの場合は Flash Size を "2M (1M SPIFFS)" に、"4M (3M SPIFFS)" にします。
items.text9: Arduino IDEの "Verify" ボタンを押し、正常にビルドできるかどうか確認してください。

items.title: Connect NinjaPCR to your PC
items.text1: 電源をケーブルをNinjaPCRに接続します。この時点で電源プラグは抜いたままにしておいてください。
items.text2: USBシリアル変換ケーブルでNinjaPCRとPCを接続します。右の6本のピンに挿します。
items.text3: 左の2本は未接続の状態にしておいてください。
items.text4: 左の2本のピンにジャンパピンを挿し込みます。
items.text5: この2本のピンが接続された状態で電源投入またはリセットを行うことで、ESP8266は通常起動モードではなくファームウェア書き込みモードで起動します。
items.text6: 電源を接続し、書き込みモードで起動します。
items.text7: なお、書き込みモードで正常に起動しているか疑わしい場合、Arduino IDEのシリアルモニタから確認することができます。Baud rateは "74880" を選択します。
items.text8: 正しくシリアル接続され、PCが認識し、書き込みモードで起動している場合は、次のように表示されます。

items.title: Burn!
items.text1: Arduino IDEの "Upload" ボタンを押すと、ビルドしたバイナリがESP8266に書き込まれます。
items.text2: 一部の環境ではArduinoからの書き込みに失敗しますが、生成されたバイナリファイルをコマンドラインツールesptool.pyを使って書き込むと成功する場合があります。
items.text3: OSや周辺ツール、書き込みに使用するツールなど環境に依存する要素が大きいので、もしうまくいかない場合は、できるだけ詳しく環境と状況を添えてお問い合わせください。

req.label: Requirements
req.text8: Wi-Fi support devices (PC, smartphone, tablet etc)
